elements.content: Electrochemical activation is an effective and simple method to obtain in-situ surface modification of MOF materials away from thermal decomposition. However, the impact of the rate and related phase transformation on OER intrinsic activity during the electrochemical activation process is often overlooked. Herein, we synthesized a kind of Co-MOF with a unique crystal structure in which the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms from two water molecules and organic linkers. The bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules can be modulated by introducing Fe into Co-MOF, causing the expedited electrochemical activation. First-principles calculations suggest the electronic state of cobalt in CoFe-MOF can be modified to alter the free energy of adsorbed intermediates. Therefore, the obtained electrocatalyst possesses the optimal OER intrinsic activity, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm–2, a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec–1, and a long-term electrochemical durability with a period of 40 h. The findings are expected to help understand the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation.
elements.clean_text: Electrochemical activation is an effective and simple method to obtain in-situ surface modification of MOF materials away from thermal decomposition. However, the impact of the rate and related phase transformation on OER intrinsic activity during the electrochemical activation process is often overlooked. Herein, we  synthesized a kind of Co-MOF with a unique crystal structure in which the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms from two water molecules and organic linkers. The bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules can be modulated by introducing Fe into Co-MOF, causing the expedited electrochemical activation. First-principles calculations suggest the electronic state of cobalt in CoFe-MOF can be modified to alter the free energy of adsorbed intermediates. Therefore, the obtained electrocatalyst possesses the optimal OER intrinsic activity, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm-2, a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec-1, and a long-term electrochemical durability with a period of 40 h. The findings are expected to help understand the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation.

elements.content: Electrochemical water splitting is a conversion and storage of energy in essence. This process can be driven by a large scale of intermittent excess electricity from renewable energy (e.g., solar and wind). As an indispensable half-reaction, the electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is subject to the sluggish kinetics owing to the four-electron reaction (4OH– → 2H2O + 4e– + O2 in alkaline media). Therefore, a great number of research efforts have been made to reduce the OER overpotential and increase the reactive kinetics for maximizing the efficiency of water splitting. The development of highly efficient and low-cost OER electrocatalysts is essential for the widespread application of this technology, aiming to compete with the expensive benchmark IrO2 and RuO2 catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Electrochemical water splitting is a conversion and storage of energy in essence. This process can be driven by a large scale of intermittent excess electricity from renewable energy (e.g., solar and wind). As an indispensable half-reaction, the electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is subject to the sluggish kinetics owing to the four-electron reaction (4OH- → 2H2O + 4e- + O2 in alkaline media). Therefore, a great number of research efforts have been made to reduce the OER overpotential and increase the reactive kinetics for maximizing the efficiency of water splitting. The development of highly efficient and low-cost OER electrocatalysts is essential for the widespread application of this technology, aiming to compete with the expensive benchmark IrO2 and RuO2 catalysts.

elements.content: Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention in the research of electrochemical water splitting taking advantage of their tunable pore structure, large surface areas, and high design flexibility. However, generally, they suffer from poor electrical conductivity and low electrochemical activity, so a much research has been devoted to modifying the component and structure of MOFs by a postprocessing method to achieve high OER performance. However, such postprocessing like thermal treatment usually involves construction of carbonous frameworks to enhance the electronic conductivity and mass diffusion, which cannot essentially tailor the OER intrinsic activity of reactive sites. Therefore, how to enhance the intrinsic activity of MOFs materials is still a significant subject in the catalytic reactions. Electrochemical activation is regarded as an effective and simple method to obtain in-situ surface modification away from thermal decomposition. To our knowledge, although some groups have obtained a superior OER property of MOFs by electrochemical activation. However, the impact of the rate and related phase transformation on OER intrinsic activity during the electrochemical activation process is often overlooked. In this context, it is necessary to explore the rate of activation and the phase transformation for MOFs materials to help understand the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation.
elements.clean_text: Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention in the research of electrochemical water splitting taking advantage of their tunable pore structure, large surface areas, and high design flexibility. However, generally, they suffer from poor electrical conductivity and low electrochemical activity, so a much research has been devoted to modifying the component and structure of MOFs by a postprocessing method to achieve high OER performance. However, such postprocessing like thermal treatment usually involves  construction of carbonous frameworks to enhance the electronic conductivity and mass diffusion, which cannot essentially tailor the OER intrinsic activity of reactive sites. Therefore, how to enhance the intrinsic activity of MOFs materials is still a significant subject in the catalytic reactions. Electrochemical activation is regarded as an effective and simple method to obtain in-situ surface modification away from thermal decomposition. To our knowledge, although some groups have obtained a superior OER property of MOFs by electrochemical activation. However, the impact of the rate and related phase transformation on OER intrinsic activity during the electrochemical activation process is often overlooked. In this context, it is necessary to explore the rate of activation and the phase transformation for MOFs materials to help understand the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation.

elements.content: In this work, a kind of Co-MOF was synthesized to show an in-situ electrochemical activation during the OER process. According to the crystal structure of Co-MOF, the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms from two water molecules and organic linkers, showing a definitive structural characterization of accessible open metal sites. The two water molecules can be removed under mild conditions, signifying that more available active metal sites can be exposed to trigger their chemical activity. Therefore, modulating the bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules is expected to optimize the OER intrinsic activity. Accordingly, we introduced Fe into Co-MOF and employed a chronopotentiometry mode to expose the open metal sites of MOFs to evaluate the impact of open metal sites on the OER intrinsic activity. A series of characterizations demonstrated that iron incorporation can not only speed up the electrochemical activation by weakening the chemical bond between the metal and the coordinated water molecule but also modify the electronic state of cobalt in Co-MOF to alter the Gibbs free energy of adsorbed intermediates based on DFT calculations. After electrochemical activation, the electrocatalyst shows the optimal OER intrinsic activity and a good electrolysis stability, outperforming the benchmark IrO2 catalyst. A deep understanding toward the important role of in-situ electrochemical activation could provide more valuable insights for developing more efficient OER catalysts.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a kind of Co-MOF was synthesized to show an in-situ electrochemical activation during the OER process. According to the crystal structure of Co-MOF, the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms from two water molecules and organic linkers, showing a definitive structural characterization of accessible open metal sites. The two water molecules can be removed under mild conditions, signifying that more available active metal sites can be exposed to trigger their chemical activity. Therefore, modulating the bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules is expected to optimize the OER intrinsic activity. Accordingly, we  introduced Fe into Co-MOF and employed a chronopotentiometry mode to expose the open metal sites of MOFs to evaluate the impact of open metal sites on the OER intrinsic activity. A series of characterizations demonstrated that iron incorporation can not only speed up the electrochemical activation by weakening the chemical bond between the metal and the coordinated water molecule but also modify the electronic state of cobalt in Co-MOF to alter the Gibbs free energy of adsorbed intermediates based on DFT calculations. After electrochemical activation, the electrocatalyst shows the optimal OER intrinsic activity and a good electrolysis stability, outperforming the benchmark IrO2 catalyst. A deep understanding toward the important role of in-situ electrochemical activation could provide more valuable insights for developing more efficient OER catalysts.

elements.content: The chronopotentiometry method with a fixed current density of 10 mA cm–2 was used to in-situ activate the MOFs (a). Both curves of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were decreased and reached a potential plateau, indicating an enhanced OER activity. In addition, the activation curve of CoFe-MOF took less time to reach a stable OER duration (around 100 s). The distinct acceleration of CoFe-MOF is displayed by the rate of potential change in the inset of a, showing that electrochemical activation was accelerated by around 7 times because of Fe incorporation. As reported by Trotochaud et al. and Zhang et al., the measured potential of Co-MOF tended to some deviation when the impurity exists. Therefore, the electrochemical activation process was also recorded in 1 M KOH solution within 2 mM Co2+ or Fe2+ (Figure S2). The potential of Co-MOF increased after addition of Co2+ impurity and decreased after addition of Fe2+ impurity, while the potential of CoFe-MOF changed little. In addition, the activation rates of both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were free of an obvious influence. The phenomenon indicated that the rate of electrochemical activation is mainly determined by the MOFs. In other words, only the Co or Fe component in the inner framework was the key factor to affect the activation rate. The dissolution of catalyst during electrochemical activation was also detected by ICP measurement (Table S1). The concentrations of Co and Fe in 1 M KOH solution were slightly increased after activation. It indicated that the expedited activation of CoFe-MOF underwent inevitable degradation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

Expedited Electrochemical Activation

The chronopotentiometry method with a fixed current density of 10 mA cm-2 was used to in-situ activate the MOFs (a). Both curves of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were decreased and  reached  a potential plateau, indicating an enhanced OER activity. In addition, the activation curve of CoFe-MOF took less time to reach  a stable OER duration (around 100 s). The distinct acceleration of CoFe-MOF is displayed by the rate of potential change in the inset of a, showing that  electrochemical activation was accelerated by around 7 times because of Fe incorporation. As reported by Trotochaud et al. and Zhang et al., the measured potential of Co-MOF tended to some deviation when the impurity exists. Therefore, the electrochemical activation process was also recorded in 1 M KOH solution within 2 mM Co2+ or Fe2+ (Figure S2). The potential of Co-MOF increased after  addition of Co2+ impurity and decreased after  addition of Fe2+ impurity, while the potential of CoFe-MOF changed little. In addition, the activation rates of both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were free of an obvious influence. The phenomenon indicated that the rate of electrochemical activation is mainly determined by the MOFs. In other words, only the Co or Fe component in the inner framework was the key factor to affect the activation rate. The dissolution of catalyst during  electrochemical activation was also detected by ICP measurement (Table S1). The concentrations of Co and Fe in 1 M KOH solution were slightly increased after activation. It indicated that the expedited activation of CoFe-MOF underwent inevitable degradation.

elements.content: (a) Chronopotentiometry activation of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF. (b) Schematic illustration of Fe assistant for in-situ electrochemical activation. (c) TG plots of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (Inset) Plots of (i) activation rate and (ii) DTG for Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Chronopotentiometry activation of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF. (b) Schematic illustration of Fe assistant for in-situ electrochemical activation. (c) TG plots of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (Inset) Plots of (i) activation rate and (ii) DTG for Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF.

elements.content: In order to explore the reason for expedited electrochemical activation, the structure of the compound should be figured out. The supramolecular network of as-prepared MOFs was composed of octahedron units (Model A in b). The neighboring units were connected in hydrogen-bonding patterns, which had strong direction to form well-defined morphologies and structures. The oxygen and nitrogen atoms from the organic linker chelated the central metal atom by a single mode in the same plane, and two water molecules coordinated in the vertical plane to adopt an octahedral geometry (Figure S3). Besides, the bond strength of the central metal ion with the ligands (M–OL) was much stronger than that with the water molecule (M–OW), meaning that the property of open metal sites was strongly associated with the state of coordinated water molecules. It was reasonable that the dehydration was expected to evaluate the bonding environment, taking place along with the strength of the chemical bond during the thermal decomposition step. Therefore, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was measured to compare the environment of open metal sites for Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF (c). The foremost weight loss of Co-MOF occurred at around 126 °C, reflecting the decomposition of water molecules coordinated from the central metal ions. Also, the mass loss was slightly larger than the calculated value of 8.9%, resulting from the absorbed water on the surface. Comparatively, the initial weight loss of CoFe-MOF was lighter than that of Co-MOF, indicating that the content of water molecules in CoFe-MOF was partially missed (Model B in b). Also, the lower dehydration temperature (120 °C) of CoFe-MOF reflected the weakening impact on the bond between water molecules and central metals after Fe incorporation (inset of c), revealing the reason for the missing coordinated water molecules. Conclusively, Fe incorporation made central metal sites expose more easily for faster electrochemical activation.
elements.clean_text: In order to explore the reason for expedited electrochemical activation, the structure of the compound should be figured out. The supramolecular network of as-prepared MOFs was composed of octahedron units (Model A in b). The neighboring units were connected in hydrogen-bonding patterns, which had strong direction to form well-defined morphologies and structures. The oxygen and nitrogen atoms from the organic linker chelated the central metal atom by a single mode in the same plane, and two water molecules coordinated in the vertical plane to adopt an octahedral geometry (Figure S3). Besides, the bond strength of the central metal ion with the ligands (M-OL) was much stronger than that with the water molecule (M-OW), meaning that the property of open metal sites was strongly associated with the state of coordinated water molecules. It was reasonable that the dehydration was expected to evaluate the bonding environment, taking place along with the strength of the chemical bond during the thermal decomposition step. Therefore,  thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was measured to compare the environment of open metal sites for Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF (c). The foremost weight loss of Co-MOF occurred at around 126 °C, reflecting the decomposition of water molecules coordinated from the central metal ions. Also, the mass loss was slightly larger than the calculated value of 8.9%, resulting from the absorbed water on the surface. Comparatively, the initial weight loss of CoFe-MOF was lighter than that of Co-MOF, indicating that the content of water molecules in CoFe-MOF was partially missed (Model B in b). Also, the lower dehydration temperature (120 °C) of CoFe-MOF reflected the weakening impact on the bond between water molecules and central metals after Fe incorporation (inset of c), revealing the reason for the missing  coordinated water molecules. Conclusively,  Fe incorporation made central metal sites expose more easily for faster electrochemical activation.

elements.content: (a) DOS of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF. (b) Number of 3d electrons for the Co atom in Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF. (c) Standard free energy diagram of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF for the OER process. (d) Potential limiting step model of OER catalysis.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) DOS of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF. (b) Number of 3d electrons for the Co atom in Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF. (c) Standard free energy diagram of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF for the OER process. (d) Potential limiting step model of OER catalysis.

elements.content: To further understand the expedited in-situ electrochemical activation by Fe incorporation, we performed the density function calculation (DFT) to elucidate the electronic environment of open metal sites. Both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF showed a density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level, which revealed a metallic behavior (a). Also, the strategy of bimetal MOF resulted in Fe states to form a delocalized and upshifted d band toward the Fermi level, suggesting that the charge carrier density of CoFe-MOF significantly increases by Fe incorporation (a). The number of 3d electrons for the Co atom in CoFe-MOF was about 7.5, less than 7.8 in Co-MOF (theoretical value for Co2+ is 7) (b). According to the mechanism of OER, the transfer of 3d orbital electrons from Co to Fe showed the electrons interaction of synergistic effects, which has been reported to facilitate the OER process. The free energy diagram of intermediates (HO*, O*, HOO*) during OER is shown in c. It can be found that the potential limiting step of both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF for the reaction path was the deprotonation of HO* to O* on Co sites. After introduction of the Fe component, the free energy value of the potential limiting step was lowered significantly (c), revealing the largely reduced energy barrier for formation of O* (d).
elements.clean_text: To further understand the expedited in-situ electrochemical activation by Fe incorporation, we performed the density function calculation (DFT) to elucidate the electronic environment of open metal sites. Both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF showed a density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level, which revealed a metallic behavior (a). Also, the strategy of bimetal MOF resulted in Fe states to form a delocalized and upshifted d band toward the Fermi level, suggesting that the charge carrier density of CoFe-MOF significantly increases by Fe incorporation (a). The number of 3d electrons for the Co atom in CoFe-MOF was about 7.5, less than 7.8 in Co-MOF (theoretical value for Co2+ is 7) (b). According to the mechanism of OER, the transfer of 3d orbital electrons from Co to Fe showed the electrons interaction of synergistic effects, which has been reported to facilitate the OER process. The free energy diagram of intermediates (HO*, O*, HOO*) during OER is shown in c. It can be found that the potential limiting step of both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF for the reaction path was the deprotonation of HO* to O* on Co sites. After introduction of the Fe component, the free energy value of the potential limiting step was lowered significantly (c), revealing the largely reduced energy barrier for formation of O* (d).

elements.content: The structural features of as-prepared MOFs were characterized by the XRD technique (a). The results verified that Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and Fe-MOF samples have a similar structure, consistent with the simulated phase of diaqua-bis­(5-carboxy-1H-imidazole-4-carboxylate)­cobalt­(II) (CCDC no. 998828). It should be pointed out that the diffraction peaks become weaker and broader for the CoFe-MOF, indicating the formation of defects after introduction of iron. The FT-IR spectrum of CoFe-MOF is shown in b, consistent with the data reported previously. The absorption band at 3322 cm–1 indicated the stretching vibrations of N–H from the imidazole ring. The appearance of a band around 1752 cm–1 showed the unprotonated carboxylic groups vibrations in the structure. The stretching vibrations of CC from the imidazole ring were observed at 1502 and 1443 cm–1. The bands at 1556 and 1398 cm–1 were assigned to COO– groups for the asymmetric and symmetric vibrational. The strong band at 1246 cm–1 was caused by the C–O stretching frequency from the deprotonated carboxylic groups. A stretching vibrational frequency was observed at 1136 cm–1 derived from the C–OH groups of COOH. In addition, the absorption bands at 647 and 528 cm–1 were mainly due to M–OW and M–OL stretching vibrations, respectively. The absorption bands at 456 cm–1 represent the central metal ion with the N (M–N) stretching vibrations. After expedited electrochemical activation, the crystallinity of CoFe-MOF-OH became much poorer, meaning more surface defects and lattice distortion to expose more open metal sites. Also, the absorption band of N–H on the imidazole ring, unprotonated COOH, and C–OH group of carboxylate disappeared attribued to their chemical instability in the alkaline solution. The M–OW vibrations for CoFe-MOF-OH were dramatically reduced, demonstrating removal of the coordinated solvent molecules to expose available sites. Meanwhile, the newly generated peak at 1620 cm–1 is characteristic of the metal–oxygen double bond in the structure of oxyhydroxide. It is worth pointing out that the potential limiting step was determined by the formation of O* intermediate based on the DFT results; generation of a metal–oxygen double bond further reflected the declining energy barrier for deprotonation of HO* to O* (d). Therefore, it can be concluded that the expedited electrochemical activation experienced a hydroxide transformation with a degradation of some organic ligands under electrochemical activation in 1 M KOH electrolyte (Model C in b), corresponding to the results of ICP measurement (Table S1).
elements.clean_text:
Phase and Morphology Analysis

The structural features of as-prepared MOFs were characterized by the XRD technique (a). The results verified that Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and Fe-MOF samples have a similar structure, consistent with the simulated phase of diaqua-bis(5-carboxy-1H-imidazole-4-carboxylate)cobalt(II) (CCDC no. 998828). It should be pointed out that the diffraction peaks become weaker and broader for the CoFe-MOF, indicating the formation of defects after  introduction of iron. The FT-IR spectrum of CoFe-MOF is shown in b, consistent with the data reported previously. The absorption band at 3322 cm-1 indicated the stretching vibrations of N-H from the imidazole ring. The appearance of a band around 1752 cm-1 showed the unprotonated carboxylic groups vibrations in the structure. The stretching vibrations of CC from the imidazole ring were observed at 1502 and 1443 cm-1. The bands at 1556 and 1398 cm-1 were assigned to COO- groups for the asymmetric and symmetric vibrational. The strong band at 1246 cm-1 was caused by the C-O stretching frequency from the deprotonated carboxylic groups. A stretching vibrational frequency was observed at 1136 cm-1 derived from the C-OH groups of COOH. In addition, the absorption bands at 647 and 528 cm-1 were mainly due to M-OW and M-OL stretching vibrations, respectively. The absorption bands at 456 cm-1 represent the central metal ion with the N (M-N) stretching vibrations. After expedited electrochemical activation, the crystallinity of CoFe-MOF-OH became much poorer, meaning more surface defects and lattice distortion to expose more open metal sites. Also, the absorption band of N-H on the imidazole ring, unprotonated COOH, and C-OH group of carboxylate disappeared attribued to their chemical instability in the alkaline solution. The M-OW vibrations for CoFe-MOF-OH were dramatically reduced, demonstrating  removal of the coordinated solvent molecules to expose available sites. Meanwhile, the newly generated peak at 1620 cm-1 is  characteristic of the metal-oxygen double bond in the structure of oxyhydroxide. It is worth  pointing out that the potential limiting step was determined by the formation of O* intermediate based on the DFT results;  generation of a metal-oxygen double bond further reflected the declining energy barrier for  deprotonation of HO* to O* (d). Therefore, it can be concluded that the expedited electrochemical activation experienced a hydroxide transformation with a degradation of some organic ligands under  electrochemical activation in 1 M KOH electrolyte (Model C in b), corresponding to the results of ICP measurement (Table S1).

elements.content: (a) Powder XRD patterns of Co-MOF, Fe-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (b) FT-IR spectra of CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Powder XRD patterns of Co-MOF, Fe-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (b) FT-IR spectra of CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH.

elements.content: The morphology was confirmed by TEM as shown in . The primary CoFe-MOF was composed of ultrathin nanosheets with an amorphous structure (a and b), corresponding to the results of XRD patterns. It is necessary to point out that Co-MOF demonstrated a nanorod morphology (c), and Fe-MOF presented as agglomerative particles with 20 nm diameter (f), indicating that introduction of Fe assisted the MOFs in forming more edge and surface defects. It should be due to the fact that the missed coordinated water molecules caused the destructive effect to the hydrogen bonding. As a result, more reactive sites should be exposed to accelerate the activation process. After electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH still preserved the 2D amorphous structure as shown in d and e. However, the shape of amorphous nanosheets transferred from angular to stable round (e), which may be attributed to the chemical activity difference between the edge and the corner region during the activation process. The elemental mapping of CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH showed that Co, Fe, N, and O were well distributed in the amorphous structure (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: The morphology was confirmed by TEM as shown in . The primary CoFe-MOF was composed of ultrathin nanosheets with an amorphous structure (a and  b), corresponding to the results of XRD patterns. It is necessary to point out that Co-MOF demonstrated a nanorod morphology (c), and Fe-MOF presented as agglomerative particles with 20 nm diameter (f), indicating that  introduction of Fe assisted the MOFs in forming more edge and surface defects. It should be due to the fact that the missed coordinated water molecules caused the destructive effect to the hydrogen bonding. As a result, more reactive sites should be exposed to accelerate the activation process. After electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH still preserved the 2D amorphous structure as shown in d and  e. However, the shape of amorphous nanosheets transferred from angular to stable round (e), which may be attributed to the chemical activity difference between the edge and the corner region during the activation process. The elemental mapping of CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH  showed that Co, Fe, N, and O were well distributed in the amorphous structure (Figure S4).

elements.content: TEM images of (a) CoFe-MOF, (d) CoFe-MOF-OH, (c) Co-MOF, and (f) Fe-MOF; magnified TEM images of (b) CoFe-MOF and (e) CoFe-MOF-OH.
elements.clean_text: 4  TEM images of (a) CoFe-MOF, (d) CoFe-MOF-OH, (c) Co-MOF, and (f) Fe-MOF; magnified TEM images of (b) CoFe-MOF and (e) CoFe-MOF-OH.

elements.content: To further prove the benefit of Fe incorporation to expedite the electrochemical activation, the surface chemical composites and states were also represented by XPS analysis. The XPS survey spectra of as-prepared MOFs confirmed the presence of C, N, O, and Co elements, and the existence of Fe signal for CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH also verified incorporation of the Fe component (Figure S5). The Co, Fe, O, and N atomic percentages of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH are shown in Table S2. The O/N ratio of Co-MOF was determined to be 2.8, larger than the theoretical value of 2.5, because of the absorbed water on the surface. After introduction of Fe, the O/N ratio was reduced to 2.6, which can be assumed that the weakening function of chemical bonds M–OW benefited the exposure of open metal sites for an expedited hydroxide transformation. However, the ratio increased rapidly to 6.1 after electrochemical activation owing to in-situ formation of the hydroxide function on open metal sites accompanying with the degradation of some organic ligands (Model C in b).
elements.clean_text:
XPS Analyses

To further prove the benefit of Fe incorporation to expedite the electrochemical activation, the surface chemical composites and states were also represented by XPS analysis. The XPS survey spectra of as-prepared MOFs confirmed the presence of C, N, O, and Co elements, and the existence of Fe signal for CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH also verified  incorporation of the Fe component (Figure S5). The Co, Fe, O, and N atomic percentages of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH are shown in Table S2. The O/N ratio of Co-MOF was determined to be 2.8, larger than the theoretical value of 2.5, because of the absorbed water on the surface. After introduction of Fe, the O/N ratio was reduced to 2.6, which can be assumed that the weakening function of chemical bonds M-OW benefited  the exposure of open metal sites for an expedited hydroxide transformation. However, the ratio increased rapidly to 6.1 after electrochemical activation owing to  in-situ formation of the hydroxide function on open metal sites accompanying with the degradation of some organic ligands (Model C in b).

elements.content: The chemical composition of open metal sites was also investigated. In the high-resolution spectrum of Co 2p for Co-MOF, the Co 2p3/2 peaks were deconvoluted into three peaks according to the connecting forms of cobalt with nitrogen and oxygen. The peaks at 782.7, 780.6, and 778.7 eV corresponded to Co–N, Co–OL, and Co–OW, respectively (a). The peak of Co–OW for CoFe-MOF notably shifted to a low binding energy (777.9 eV) compared to the pristine Co-MOF, further proving the Fe accelerated removal of a coordinated water molecule to expose the open metal sites. The component ratios of Co–N/Co–OW and Co–OL/Co–OW were calculated from the fitted Co 2p XPS spectra for Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH (Table S3). It was found that the ratios of Co–N/Co-OW and Co–OL/Co–OW rose synchronously after Fe incorporation, consistent with partially missing a coordinated water molecule. In addition, the ratio of Co–OL/Co–OW for CoFe-MOF-OH jumped to a high value, reflecting the in-situ surface hydroxide transformation of open metal sites during electrochemical activation. It is worth mentioning that the TG plot of CoFe-MOF-OH presented two marked weight losses in c, in accordance with the phase transformation of oxyhydroxide to oxides, which agrees with the results of FT-IR (b).
elements.clean_text: The chemical composition of open metal sites was also investigated. In the high-resolution spectrum of Co 2p for Co-MOF, the Co 2p3/2 peaks were deconvoluted into three peaks according to the connecting forms of cobalt with nitrogen and oxygen. The peaks at 782.7, 780.6, and 778.7 eV  corresponded to Co-N, Co-OL, and Co-OW, respectively (a). The peak of Co-OW for CoFe-MOF notably shifted to a low binding energy (777.9 eV) compared to the pristine Co-MOF, further proving the Fe accelerated  removal of a coordinated water molecule to expose the open metal sites. The component ratios of Co-N/Co-OW and Co-OL/Co-OW were calculated from the fitted Co 2p XPS spectra for Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH (Table S3). It was  found that the ratios of Co-N/Co-OW and Co-OL/Co-OW rose synchronously after  Fe incorporation, consistent with  partially missing a coordinated water molecule. In addition, the ratio of Co-OL/Co-OW for CoFe-MOF-OH jumped to a high value, reflecting the in-situ surface hydroxide transformation of open metal sites during  electrochemical activation. It is worth mentioning that the TG plot of CoFe-MOF-OH presented two marked weight losses in c, in accordance with the phase transformation of oxyhydroxide to oxides, which agrees with the results of FT-IR (b).

elements.content: High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) Co 2p and (b) O 1s of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH.
elements.clean_text: 5  High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) Co 2p and (b) O 1s of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH.

elements.content: The high-resolution spectra of O 1s were also measured to monitor the surface hydroxide transformation (b). The peaks of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were clearly deconvoluted into four types at around 527.9, 530.0, 531.1, and 532.0 eV, which can be assigned to the oxygen configuration in metal–O, −OH groups, O–C/OC, and water molecules, respectively. For CoFe-MOF-OH, a significant increase of −OH groups can be observed due to the surface hydroxide transformation. Notably, the high content of surface functional group (−OH) for CoFe-MOF-OH verified more accessible open metal sites participating in the OER process. On the other hand, the surface hydroxyl was favorable to water oxidation owing to the character of ion-permeable and superhydrophilic compounds.
elements.clean_text: The high-resolution spectra of O 1s were also measured to monitor the surface hydroxide transformation (b). The peaks of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were clearly deconvoluted into four types at around 527.9, 530.0, 531.1, and 532.0 eV, which can be assigned to the oxygen configuration in metal-O, -OH groups, O-C/OC, and water molecules, respectively. For CoFe-MOF-OH, a significant increase of -OH groups can be observed due to the surface hydroxide transformation. Notably, the high content of surface functional group (-OH) for CoFe-MOF-OH verified more accessible open metal sites participating in the OER process. On the other hand, the surface hydroxyl was favorable to water oxidation owing to the character of ion-permeable and superhydrophilic compounds.

elements.content: The electrocatalytic performance was measured in 1 M KOH electrolyte, and all of the catalysts were loaded onto a glass carbon electrode by simple drop casting with a loading of 0.212 mg cm–2. Fe-MOF showed a very low current density even at high overpotential, suggesting the poor activity for OER (a). On the contrary, CoFe-MOF exhibited a low overpotential of 351 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, lower than that of Co-MOF (385 mV), suggesting an enhanced OER performance. A small Tafel slope of CoFe-MOF was 44 mV dec–1, which can provide a significantly increased OER rate with the increased overpotentials (b). By virtue of the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under different scan rates, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was obtained from calculation of the electrochemical double-layer capacitances (C dl) (Figure S6). As a result, CoFe-MOF manifested the largest values of C dl (0.40 mF cm–2), implying a great number of active sites (c). After electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited the lowest overpotential of 310 mV, which was 41 mV lower than that of CoFe-MOF, and it was also superior to benchmark IrO2 in the high potential range (a). The Tafel slope and the C dl of CoFe-MOF-OH still remained a reasonable value. To estimate the intrinsic activities of catalysts, the LSV curves of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, Fe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH were normalized by ECSA (d). CoFe-MOF-OH showed the best OER activity after expedited electrochemical activation, which reflected the real principle for the improved OER performance. Likewise, the TOF value was also related with the intrinsic activity. CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited a remarkable TOF value of 0.4004 s–1 at an overpotential of 400 mV, far exceeding the CoFe-MOF and Co-MOF (e). Moreover, CoFe-MOF-OH also demonstrated good long-term electrochemical durability for at least 40 h (f). Also, oxygen production remained at a larger current density of 50 mA cm–2 for about 12 h (Figure S7). In order to distinguish the measured current density deriving from the possible dissolution of catalyst, the content of Co and Fe in the electrolyte after the OER duration of 20 and 40 h was also detected by ICP. As shown in Table S1, the deviation of their content in electrolyte is negligible after a long time stability test, indicating the measured current exclusively to the OER as opposed to possible dissolution of the catalyst’s constituents. Comprehensively, the electrocatalyst treated with a period of 40 h OER was also surveyed. The electrocatalyst completely reconstructed to 3D crystalline metal oxides (Figure S8). It was interesting that the metal oxides were detected until around 10 min (Figure S8a). It can be seen that the transition state of CoFe-MOF-OH was an indispensable bridging between CoFe-MOF and (Fe1–x Co x )2O3 to contribute to the exposure of active sites. In addition, the native (Fe1–x Co x )2O3, which was directly synthesized by a hydrothermal method, showed a rather poor OER activity and small electrochemically active surface area (Figure S9). In other words, the OER property of derived (Fe1–x Co x )2O3 was still strongly associated with the structure-dependent catalytic performance.
elements.clean_text:
OER Property

The electrocatalytic performance was measured in 1 M KOH electrolyte, and all of the catalysts were loaded onto a glass carbon electrode by simple drop casting with a loading of 0.212 mg cm-2. Fe-MOF showed a very low current density even at high overpotential, suggesting the poor activity for OER (a). On the contrary, CoFe-MOF exhibited a low overpotential of 351 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm-2, lower than that of Co-MOF (385 mV), suggesting an enhanced OER performance. A small Tafel slope of CoFe-MOF was 44 mV dec-1, which can provide a significantly increased OER rate with the increased overpotentials (b). By virtue of the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under different scan rates, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was obtained from  calculation of the electrochemical double-layer capacitances (C dl) (Figure S6). As a result, CoFe-MOF manifested the largest values of C dl (0.40 mF cm-2), implying a great number of active sites (c). After electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited the lowest overpotential of 310 mV, which was 41 mV lower than that of CoFe-MOF, and it was also superior to benchmark IrO2 in the high potential range (a). The Tafel slope and the C dl of CoFe-MOF-OH still remained a reasonable value. To estimate the intrinsic activities of catalysts, the LSV curves of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, Fe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH were normalized by ECSA (d). CoFe-MOF-OH showed the best OER activity after expedited electrochemical activation, which reflected the real principle for the improved OER performance. Likewise, the TOF value was also related with the intrinsic activity. CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited a remarkable TOF value of 0.4004 s-1 at an overpotential of 400 mV, far exceeding the CoFe-MOF and Co-MOF (e). Moreover, CoFe-MOF-OH also demonstrated good long-term electrochemical durability for at least 40 h (f). Also,  oxygen production remained at a larger current density of 50 mA cm-2 for about 12 h (Figure S7). In order to distinguish the measured current density deriving from the possible dissolution of catalyst, the content of Co and Fe in the electrolyte after the OER duration of 20 and 40 h was also detected by ICP. As shown in Table S1, the deviation of their content in electrolyte is negligible after a long time stability test, indicating the measured current exclusively to the OER as opposed to possible dissolution of the catalyst's constituents. Comprehensively, the electrocatalyst treated with a period of 40 h OER was also surveyed. The electrocatalyst completely reconstructed to 3D crystalline metal oxides (Figure S8). It was interesting that the metal oxides were detected until around 10 min (Figure S8a). It can be seen that the transition state of CoFe-MOF-OH was an indispensable bridging between CoFe-MOF and (Fe1-x Co x )2O3 to contribute to the exposure of active sites. In addition, the native (Fe1-x Co x )2O3, which was directly synthesized by a hydrothermal method, showed a rather poor OER activity and small electrochemically active surface area (Figure S9). In other words, the OER property of derived (Fe1-x Co x )2O3 was still strongly associated with the structure-dependent catalytic performance.

elements.content: (a) LSV curves and (b) Tafel plots of Co-MOF, Fe-MOF, CoFe-MOF, CoFe-MOF-OH, and IrO2 in 1 M KOH electrolyte. (c) C dl curves and (d) LSV curves normalized by ECSA of Co-MOF, Fe-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (e) TOF of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (f) Chronopotentiometric curve of CoFe-MOF-OH in 1 M KOH electrolyte at a fixed current density of 10 mA cm–2. (g) Comparison of electrochemical impedance spectra between CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH in 1 M KOH electrolyte. (Inset) Equivalent circuit of CoFe-MOF-OH.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) LSV curves and (b) Tafel plots of Co-MOF, Fe-MOF, CoFe-MOF, CoFe-MOF-OH, and IrO2 in 1 M KOH electrolyte. (c) C dl curves and (d) LSV curves normalized by ECSA of Co-MOF, Fe-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (e) TOF of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH. (f) Chronopotentiometric curve of CoFe-MOF-OH in 1 M KOH electrolyte at a fixed current density of 10 mA cm-2. (g) Comparison of electrochemical impedance spectra between CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH in 1 M KOH electrolyte. (Inset) Equivalent circuit of CoFe-MOF-OH.

elements.content: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then measured to further probe the transfer kinetics of charge carriers. CoFe-MOF exhibited a small charge transfer resistance (R ct) of 19.2 ohm at a potential of 1.58 V vs RHE, correlated with the fast kinetics of water oxidation, which was far less than that of Co-MOF (114 ohm) and Fe-MOF (949 ohm) (Figure S10). The improvement was also echoed to the DFT calculation. Notably, two semicircles were recorded for CoFe-MOF-OH in the Nyquist plots, indicative of two time-constant behavior (g). The first semicircle appearing in the high-frequency region reflected the charge-transfer resistance (R ct), while the emerging low-frequency semicircle was corresponding to the adsorption of reactive intermediate on the electrode surface, representing the nature of the surface hydroxide transformation at the open metal sites. One can see that the stimulated R ct value for CoFe-MOF-OH was determined to be 17.3 ohm smaller than that of initial CoFe-MOF, revealing a faster charge transfer owing to an in-situ electrochemical activation to form hydroxide species.
elements.clean_text: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then measured to further probe the transfer kinetics of charge carriers. CoFe-MOF exhibited a small charge transfer resistance (R ct) of 19.2 ohm at a potential of 1.58 V vs RHE, correlated with the fast kinetics of water oxidation, which was far less than that of Co-MOF (114 ohm) and Fe-MOF (949 ohm) (Figure S10). The improvement was also echoed to the DFT calculation. Notably,  two semicircles were recorded for CoFe-MOF-OH in the Nyquist plots, indicative of two time-constant behavior (g). The first semicircle appearing in the high-frequency region reflected the charge-transfer resistance (R ct), while the emerging low-frequency semicircle was corresponding to the adsorption of reactive intermediate on the electrode surface, representing the nature of the surface hydroxide transformation at the open metal sites. One can see that the stimulated R ct value for CoFe-MOF-OH was determined to be 17.3 ohm smaller than that of initial CoFe-MOF, revealing a faster charge transfer owing to an in-situ electrochemical activation to form hydroxide species.

elements.content: It should be noted that integration conducting materials like carbon substrate, Ni foam, and Cu foil with electrocatalysts have much better electrochemical performance than their bulks due to faster carrier transport, more active sites, and other synergistic effects. In this way we fabricated the electrodes by combining CoFe-MOF with Ni foam (CoFe-MOF NF for short). As expected, the CoFe-MOF-OH NF gave much improved OER activities, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm–2 (Figure S11).
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that integration conducting materials like carbon substrate, Ni foam, and Cu foil with electrocatalysts have much better electrochemical performance than their bulks due to faster carrier transport, more active sites, and other synergistic effects. In this way we  fabricated the electrodes by combining CoFe-MOF with Ni foam (CoFe-MOF NF for short). As expected, the CoFe-MOF-OH NF gave much improved OER activities, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm-2 (Figure S11).

elements.content: Co-MOF with a unique crystal structure was successfully synthesized by a hydrothermal process in which the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen from two water molecules and organic linkers. The bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules could be modulated by introducing Fe into Co-MOF to accelerate the rate of CoFe-MOF during the electrochemical activation process. Besides, the Fe component could optimize the electronic structure of open metal sites and reduce the free energy of adsorbed intermediates, which was responsible for the enhanced OER intrinsic activity. After an in-situ electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH possessed optimal OER intrinsic activity, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm–2, a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec–1, and good long-term stability for at least 40 h. These findings may supply new insight into understanding the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation for developing highly efficient OER catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Co-MOF with a unique crystal structure was successfully synthesized by a hydrothermal process in which the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen from two water molecules and organic linkers. The bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules could be modulated by introducing Fe into Co-MOF to accelerate the rate of CoFe-MOF during the electrochemical activation process. Besides, the Fe component could optimize the electronic structure of open metal sites and reduce the free energy of adsorbed intermediates, which was responsible for the enhanced OER intrinsic activity. After an in-situ electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH possessed  optimal OER intrinsic activity, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm-2, a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec-1, and good long-term stability for at least 40 h. These findings may supply new insight into understanding the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation for developing highly efficient OER catalysts.

cln_elements.content:
Electrochemical activation is an effective and simple method to obtain in-situ surface modification of MOF materials away from thermal decomposition. However, the impact of the rate and related phase transformation on OER intrinsic activity during the electrochemical activation process is often overlooked. Herein, we synthesized a kind of Co-MOF with a unique crystal structure in which the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms from two water molecules and organic linkers. The bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules can be modulated by introducing Fe into Co-MOF, causing the expedited electrochemical activation. First-principles calculations suggest the electronic state of cobalt in CoFe-MOF can be modified to alter the free energy of adsorbed intermediates. Therefore, the obtained electrocatalyst possesses the optimal OER intrinsic activity, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm–2, a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec–1, and a long-term electrochemical durability with a period of 40 h. The findings are expected to help understand the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation.

Results and DiscussionsExpedited Electrochemical Activation

The chronopotentiometry method with a fixed current density of 10 mA cm–2 was used to in-situ activate the MOFs (a). Both curves of Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were decreased and reached a potential plateau, indicating an enhanced OER activity. In addition, the activation curve of CoFe-MOF took less time to reach a stable OER duration (around 100 s). The distinct acceleration of CoFe-MOF is displayed by the rate of potential change in the inset of a, showing that electrochemical activation was accelerated by around 7 times because of Fe incorporation. As reported by Trotochaud et al. and Zhang et al., the measured potential of Co-MOF tended to some deviation when the impurity exists. Therefore, the electrochemical activation process was also recorded in 1 M KOH solution within 2 mM Co2+ or Fe2+ (Figure S2). The potential of Co-MOF increased after addition of Co2+ impurity and decreased after addition of Fe2+ impurity, while the potential of CoFe-MOF changed little. In addition, the activation rates of both Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF were free of an obvious influence. The phenomenon indicated that the rate of electrochemical activation is mainly determined by the MOFs. In other words, only the Co or Fe component in the inner framework was the key factor to affect the activation rate. The dissolution of catalyst during electrochemical activation was also detected by ICP measurement (Table S1). The concentrations of Co and Fe in 1 M KOH solution were slightly increased after activation. It indicated that the expedited activation of CoFe-MOF underwent inevitable degradation.

In order to explore the reason for expedited electrochemical activation, the structure of the compound should be figured out. The supramolecular network of as-prepared MOFs was composed of octahedron units (Model A in b). The neighboring units were connected in hydrogen-bonding patterns, which had strong direction to form well-defined morphologies and structures. The oxygen and nitrogen atoms from the organic linker chelated the central metal atom by a single mode in the same plane, and two water molecules coordinated in the vertical plane to adopt an octahedral geometry (Figure S3). Besides, the bond strength of the central metal ion with the ligands (M–OL) was much stronger than that with the water molecule (M–OW), meaning that the property of open metal sites was strongly associated with the state of coordinated water molecules. It was reasonable that the dehydration was expected to evaluate the bonding environment, taking place along with the strength of the chemical bond during the thermal decomposition step. Therefore, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was measured to compare the environment of open metal sites for Co-MOF and CoFe-MOF (c). The foremost weight loss of Co-MOF occurred at around 126 °C, reflecting the decomposition of water molecules coordinated from the central metal ions. Also, the mass loss was slightly larger than the calculated value of 8.9%, resulting from the absorbed water on the surface. Comparatively, the initial weight loss of CoFe-MOF was lighter than that of Co-MOF, indicating that the content of water molecules in CoFe-MOF was partially missed (Model B in b). Also, the lower dehydration temperature (120 °C) of CoFe-MOF reflected the weakening impact on the bond between water molecules and central metals after Fe incorporation (inset of c), revealing the reason for the missing coordinated water molecules. Conclusively, Fe incorporation made central metal sites expose more easily for faster electrochemical activation.

XPS Analyses

To further prove the benefit of Fe incorporation to expedite the electrochemical activation, the surface chemical composites and states were also represented by XPS analysis. The XPS survey spectra of as-prepared MOFs confirmed the presence of C, N, O, and Co elements, and the existence of Fe signal for CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH also verified incorporation of the Fe component (Figure S5). The Co, Fe, O, and N atomic percentages of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH are shown in Table S2. The O/N ratio of Co-MOF was determined to be 2.8, larger than the theoretical value of 2.5, because of the absorbed water on the surface. After introduction of Fe, the O/N ratio was reduced to 2.6, which can be assumed that the weakening function of chemical bonds M–OW benefited the exposure of open metal sites for an expedited hydroxide transformation. However, the ratio increased rapidly to 6.1 after electrochemical activation owing to in-situ formation of the hydroxide function on open metal sites accompanying with the degradation of some organic ligands (Model C in b).

OER Property

The electrocatalytic performance was measured in 1 M KOH electrolyte, and all of the catalysts were loaded onto a glass carbon electrode by simple drop casting with a loading of 0.212 mg cm–2. Fe-MOF showed a very low current density even at high overpotential, suggesting the poor activity for OER (a). On the contrary, CoFe-MOF exhibited a low overpotential of 351 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, lower than that of Co-MOF (385 mV), suggesting an enhanced OER performance. A small Tafel slope of CoFe-MOF was 44 mV dec–1, which can provide a significantly increased OER rate with the increased overpotentials (b). By virtue of the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under different scan rates, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was obtained from calculation of the electrochemical double-layer capacitances (C dl) (Figure S6). As a result, CoFe-MOF manifested the largest values of C dl (0.40 mF cm–2), implying a great number of active sites (c). After electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited the lowest overpotential of 310 mV, which was 41 mV lower than that of CoFe-MOF, and it was also superior to benchmark IrO2 in the high potential range (a). The Tafel slope and the C dl of CoFe-MOF-OH still remained a reasonable value. To estimate the intrinsic activities of catalysts, the LSV curves of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, Fe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH were normalized by ECSA (d). CoFe-MOF-OH showed the best OER activity after expedited electrochemical activation, which reflected the real principle for the improved OER performance. Likewise, the TOF value was also related with the intrinsic activity. CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited a remarkable TOF value of 0.4004 s–1 at an overpotential of 400 mV, far exceeding the CoFe-MOF and Co-MOF (e). Moreover, CoFe-MOF-OH also demonstrated good long-term electrochemical durability for at least 40 h (f). Also, oxygen production remained at a larger current density of 50 mA cm–2 for about 12 h (Figure S7). In order to distinguish the measured current density deriving from the possible dissolution of catalyst, the content of Co and Fe in the electrolyte after the OER duration of 20 and 40 h was also detected by ICP. As shown in Table S1, the deviation of their content in electrolyte is negligible after a long time stability test, indicating the measured current exclusively to the OER as opposed to possible dissolution of the catalyst’s constituents. Comprehensively, the electrocatalyst treated with a period of 40 h OER was also surveyed. The electrocatalyst completely reconstructed to 3D crystalline metal oxides (Figure S8). It was interesting that the metal oxides were detected until around 10 min (Figure S8a). It can be seen that the transition state of CoFe-MOF-OH was an indispensable bridging between CoFe-MOF and (Fe1–x Co x )2O3 to contribute to the exposure of active sites. In addition, the native (Fe1–x Co x )2O3, which was directly synthesized by a hydrothermal method, showed a rather poor OER activity and small electrochemically active surface area (Figure S9). In other words, the OER property of derived (Fe1–x Co x )2O3 was still strongly associated with the structure-dependent catalytic performance.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then measured to further probe the transfer kinetics of charge carriers. CoFe-MOF exhibited a small charge transfer resistance (R ct) of 19.2 ohm at a potential of 1.58 V vs RHE, correlated with the fast kinetics of water oxidation, which was far less than that of Co-MOF (114 ohm) and Fe-MOF (949 ohm) (Figure S10). The improvement was also echoed to the DFT calculation. Notably, two semicircles were recorded for CoFe-MOF-OH in the Nyquist plots, indicative of two time-constant behavior (g). The first semicircle appearing in the high-frequency region reflected the charge-transfer resistance (R ct), while the emerging low-frequency semicircle was corresponding to the adsorption of reactive intermediate on the electrode surface, representing the nature of the surface hydroxide transformation at the open metal sites. One can see that the stimulated R ct value for CoFe-MOF-OH was determined to be 17.3 ohm smaller than that of initial CoFe-MOF, revealing a faster charge transfer owing to an in-situ electrochemical activation to form hydroxide species.

It should be noted that integration conducting materials like carbon substrate, Ni foam, and Cu foil with electrocatalysts have much better electrochemical performance than their bulks due to faster carrier transport, more active sites, and other synergistic effects. In this way we fabricated the electrodes by combining CoFe-MOF with Ni foam (CoFe-MOF NF for short). As expected, the CoFe-MOF-OH NF gave much improved OER activities, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm–2 (Figure S11).

Electrochemical activation is an effective and simple method to obtain in-situ surface modification of MOF materials away from thermal decomposition. However, the impact of the rate and related phase transformation on OER intrinsic activity during the electrochemical activation process is often overlooked. Herein, we  synthesized a kind of Co-MOF with a unique crystal structure in which the center metals were coordinated with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms from two water molecules and organic linkers. The bond strength between the center metals and the coordinated water molecules can be modulated by introducing Fe into Co-MOF, causing the expedited electrochemical activation. First-principles calculations suggest the electronic state of cobalt in CoFe-MOF can be modified to alter the free energy of adsorbed intermediates. Therefore, the obtained electrocatalyst possesses the optimal OER intrinsic activity, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm-2, a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec-1, and a long-term electrochemical durability with a period of 40 h. The findings are expected to help understand the fundamental principles of electrochemical activation.

Results and Discussions

Expedited Electrochemical Activation

The chronopotentiometry method with a fixed current density of 10 mA cm-2 was used to in-situ activate the MOFs (a). Also, the lower dehydration temperature (120 °C) of CoFe-MOF reflected the weakening impact on the bond between water molecules and central metals after Fe incorporation (inset of c), revealing the reason for the missing  coordinated water molecules. To further prove the benefit of Fe incorporation to expedite the electrochemical activation, the surface chemical composites and states were also represented by XPS analysis. The XPS survey spectra of as-prepared MOFs confirmed the presence of C, N, O, and Co elements, and the existence of Fe signal for CoFe-MOF and CoFe-MOF-OH also verified  incorporation of the Fe component (Figure S5). However, the ratio increased rapidly to 6.1 after electrochemical activation owing to  in-situ formation of the hydroxide function on open metal sites accompanying with the degradation of some organic ligands (Model C in b).

The electrocatalytic performance was measured in 1 M KOH electrolyte, and all of the catalysts were loaded onto a glass carbon electrode by simple drop casting with a loading of 0.212 mg cm-2. Fe-MOF showed a very low current density even at high overpotential, suggesting the poor activity for OER (a). On the contrary, CoFe-MOF exhibited a low overpotential of 351 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm-2, lower than that of Co-MOF (385 mV), suggesting an enhanced OER performance. A small Tafel slope of CoFe-MOF was 44 mV dec-1, which can provide a significantly increased OER rate with the increased overpotentials (b). By virtue of the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under different scan rates, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was obtained from  calculation of the electrochemical double-layer capacitances (C dl) (Figure S6). As a result, CoFe-MOF manifested the largest values of C dl (0.40 mF cm-2), implying a great number of active sites (c). After electrochemical activation, CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited the lowest overpotential of 310 mV, which was 41 mV lower than that of CoFe-MOF, and it was also superior to benchmark IrO2 in the high potential range (a). The Tafel slope and the C dl of CoFe-MOF-OH still remained a reasonable value. To estimate the intrinsic activities of catalysts, the LSV curves of Co-MOF, CoFe-MOF, Fe-MOF, and CoFe-MOF-OH were normalized by ECSA (d). CoFe-MOF-OH showed the best OER activity after expedited electrochemical activation, which reflected the real principle for the improved OER performance. Likewise, the TOF value was also related with the intrinsic activity. CoFe-MOF-OH exhibited a remarkable TOF value of 0.4004 s-1 at an overpotential of 400 mV, far exceeding the CoFe-MOF and Co-MOF (e). Moreover, CoFe-MOF-OH also demonstrated good long-term electrochemical durability for at least 40 h (f). Also,  oxygen production remained at a larger current density of 50 mA cm-2 for about 12 h (Figure S7). In order to distinguish the measured current density deriving from the possible dissolution of catalyst, the content of Co and Fe in the electrolyte after the OER duration of 20 and 40 h was also detected by ICP. As shown in Table S1, the deviation of their content in electrolyte is negligible after a long time stability test, indicating the measured current exclusively to the OER as opposed to possible dissolution of the catalyst's constituents. Comprehensively, the electrocatalyst treated with a period of 40 h OER was also surveyed. The electrocatalyst completely reconstructed to 3D crystalline metal oxides (Figure S8). It was interesting that the metal oxides were detected until around 10 min (Figure S8a). It can be seen that the transition state of CoFe-MOF-OH was an indispensable bridging between CoFe-MOF and (Fe1-x Co x )2O3 to contribute to the exposure of active sites. In addition, the native (Fe1-x Co x )2O3, which was directly synthesized by a hydrothermal method, showed a rather poor OER activity and small electrochemically active surface area (Figure S9). In other words, the OER property of derived (Fe1-x Co x )2O3 was still strongly associated with the structure-dependent catalytic performance. 

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then measured to further probe the transfer kinetics of charge carriers. CoFe-MOF exhibited a small charge transfer resistance (R ct) of 19.2 ohm at a potential of 1.58 V vs RHE, correlated with the fast kinetics of water oxidation, which was far less than that of Co-MOF (114 ohm) and Fe-MOF (949 ohm) (Figure S10). The improvement was also echoed to the DFT calculation. Notably,  two semicircles were recorded for CoFe-MOF-OH in the Nyquist plots, indicative of two time-constant behavior (g). The first semicircle appearing in the high-frequency region reflected the charge-transfer resistance (R ct), while the emerging low-frequency semicircle was corresponding to the adsorption of reactive intermediate on the electrode surface, representing the nature of the surface hydroxide transformation at the open metal sites. One can see that the stimulated R ct value for CoFe-MOF-OH was determined to be 17.3 ohm smaller than that of initial CoFe-MOF, revealing a faster charge transfer owing to an in-situ electrochemical activation to form hydroxide species.

It should be noted that integration conducting materials like carbon substrate, Ni foam, and Cu foil with electrocatalysts have much better electrochemical performance than their bulks due to faster carrier transport, more active sites, and other synergistic effects. In this way we  fabricated the electrodes by combining CoFe-MOF with Ni foam (CoFe-MOF NF for short). As expected, the CoFe-MOF-OH NF gave much improved OER activities, showing a low overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm-2 (Figure S11).

metadata.title:
Expediting in-Situ Electrochemical Activation of Two-Dimensional
Metal–Organic Frameworks for Enhanced OER Intrinsic Activity
by Iron Incorporation
